issue.title: Travis build failing due to old version of golang
issue.body:
Travis build for coala/coala-bears/#2836 is failing with the following error:
# golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter
../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter/bexport.go:212: obj.IsAlias undefined (type *types.TypeName has no field or method IsAlias)

../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/packagesdriver/sizes.go:94: undefined: types.SizesFor
The command ".ci/deps.go.sh" failed and exited with 2 during .

Currently Travis CI testing is done on trusty, so either the latest version of golang needs to be manually installed in trusty images or an updated version of ubuntu needs to be used for testing.
Further input from maintainers is required to come at a conclusion.

issue.title: Adding_CI.rst: Section on Circle CI
issue.body:
In Adding_CI.rst, we have a section on Circle CI.
It appears to me that we are no longer using Circle CI (the last build for coala/coala was 2 months ago and for coala/coala-bears was 6 months ago (which is still running on the unsupported CircleCI 1.0). Also the link to coala's circle.yml is broken.
There are two solutions to this:

If we are no longer using Circle CI (which appears to be the case) then the section or at least the link needs to be removed.
If we are using it, we still need to remove/update the link and also upgrade to Circle CI 2.0 for coala-bears (which should be done via a separate issue).

This issue requires some advice and input from the maintainers but regardless of that, this would be an issue that is suitable for newcomers.

issue.title: Create a line length test helper
issue.body:
A line length test helper will take a chunk of source , and a regex, and verify the bear accepts source under the line length and rejects lines over the line length.
The max_line_length setting can be automatically determined by the lines in the source provided by the caller.  The bear should pass this test.
The regex is then used to increase the size of the source line lengths by 1 character, in accordance with the source language rules.
The helper confirms that the source was increased by 1 character only, and re-runs the bear, and expects it to fail.

issue.title: Add output mode to emit a unified diff
issue.body:
It can be useful to use coala to obtain a patch file of fixes that have been found by the bears.
For simplicity, unified diff output format should be the only format initially.
--json will be a bit of a guide on how to do this.
One way to solve this is to write a converter of the JSON output to a unified diff format, discarding all the non-fix results.

issue.title: The glob `*` does not match all bears
issue.body:
Many bears' result.origin is not just the name of the bear. For e.g.. ESLintBear has result.origin "ESLintBear (prettier/prettier)" and the glob * doesn't match anything with file seperators in it i.e. / or \, we have to use glob **. The PR #5017 fixes the issue with --apply-patches command line argument but if the .coafile has something like this
default_actions = *: ApplyPatchAction

This may not match all bears. This needs to be solved. Many things can be done to solve this eg:


The result.origin of those bears can be changed


I don't think that any user will think this through and use glob * specifically to ignore such bears so we can internally change all the glob * to **


We can prompt the user that some bears won't if they ever use the glob *


status/needs discussion on what is the best solution

issue.title: Bear Results not displayed in correct order
In `ask_for_action_and_apply()`, if `apply_single` is non-False, function should return when match is found
issue.body:
In the function ask_for_action_and_apply() in ConsoleInteraction.py, if the apply_single parameter is non-False, then the for loop inside it iterates through the entire metadata_list before returning False.
IMHO we should include a break statement inside the if block (which is in the for loop) such that the function may return after a match is found because there is no need to go through the remaining actions in metadata_list.

issue.title: Addition of Micro controllers and Micro Processors grammars in coala-antlr
issue.body:
Particularly i will start by adding the grammars which will be asm8080,asm8086 which is intel based processors.For that language definitions for the same will be added in coala.Now the bears for them will be added as of now there are no bears which works for the microprocessors or microcontrollers.Similarly a grammar will be updated on upstream for PIC microcontrollers where a language definition will also be included in coala for the same.Henceforth the bears for the microcontroller and microprocessors will be supported by this project.Basically bears will be used to style the opcode like capitalization of special functions registers etc. which are used for ADC, sensors interfacing.
Apart from this i am planning to make a tree rewriting based on the above grammars generated trees it could be done using the generated template, if it is possible
"without having that functionality on the upstream antlr".

issue.title: Project Proposal: Improvements and Enhancements in coala community & projects website
issue.body:
Project Proposal
Improvements and Enhancements in community website
Enhancements


Gamification Leaderboard

Addition of a new column named issues that will show all the labels of issues that user has solved.
Addition of a Search bar where a user can search any username in case there is a long record displayed on the page and a filter option can also be provided where the user wants to view a set of records according to his needs.
If possible, we can add a new column in leaderboard which will display the total time taken by the user to solve all the issues that were assigned to him.
Instead of displaying activities on the leaderboard page we can show these activities on the profile page (to be created) as it will save space on the leaderboard page and we can accumulate more data and columns.
Filtering of records between GCI participants and NON-GCI participants.
(Thinking on) Changing static website to dynamic website because the records of users are not static they change with time as they gain new skills, solve new issues, no more a GCI participant as they are have grown up etc.



Homepage

We can show up a leaderboard that shows up top 10 contributors of the current month(a drop-down having options with the weekly, monthly or yearly view) and NON-GCI and GCI participants will have a separate leaderboard, will have a drop-down option.



Add Login/Sign-up using GitHub


Create Profile Page

Requirements: User should be logged in using GitHub
Display all user related information and stats like it's rank, issues solved by that user, graph, contribution details and many more.



User

If possible, we can store the contribution details of users i.e. how much a user has contributed to which repository/community more and we can display that data on the graph or in some other format.
In Leaderboard, we can set username a hyperlink which will link to a profile page of the user(to be created).



Improvements


Gamification Leaderboard

Display all rendered results in a table format because currently the results are shown in a paragraph format
To make it more creative, we can show some medals/badge emojis based on data in badges columns and show these emoji beside the username.



UI

Re-designing of the website and making it responsive so that it looks good on different devices.
In Inactive Issue and unassigned issues activity web pages, instead of showing just JSON they should be displayed in proper format with some extra important information.
Contributors and Meta-Review data web pages should be redesignedto make it look good.



Improvements and Enhancements in projects website
Enhancements

In reference to project proposal #394

Currently, the website shows all projects together (Completed, Disabled and Open projects). Instead of showing them together we can group this projects so that user can easily navigate to any section.
A new section can be added that can show the count of grouped projects(e.g. their x open projects, y disabled projects and z completed projects).
Also, IMO we can show stats of projects like how many new projects proposals were accepted out which how many were completed and compare it with previous years data. (Thinking more on it if it can be more enhanced).
Since coala provides a linter for the code so we can provide information on how a particular completed project will benefit other orgs. And how they can use them in there code maintenance.
PENDING: Requirement analysis of other GSoC and GCI Orgs.



Improvements

UI

Add UI to reports page that lists all previous year GSOC project.
Improve UI of user reports page.
The responsive view looks to ugly need to be improved and materialize.css should be replaced by bootstrap.
Language drop-down at the bottom of the page doesn't seem to be working so either it should be removed or add some functionality to implement that language changer of the page.

issue.title: Enhance coala-html and integrate into coala core
issue.body:
https://github.com/coala/coala-html is a nice project, but it is an angular application which limits its user scenario and popularity. Users have to install and run an angular application to see the results. What we could possibly do is to make use of coala-html, enhance it and integrate it with coala core. Maybe as a coala CLI option, e.g. '--generate_report'. When using that option, static web pages will be generated.
https://github.com/pyta-uoft/pyta is a project initiated by the University of Toronto. It looks like a minified version of coala, but is designed to be beginner-friendly. After running the tool, it does not generate reports via CLI, but via static web pages. The attached zip file is a sample report generated by pyta.
PyTA Error Report.html.zip

coala/corobo#190.

corobo rebuild travis|circle|appveyor <PR number>.

issue.title: JSON result reporter tool
issue.body:
The coala json format provides a stable output.
There are other formats which are useful for reporting tests and failures.
Most commonly used is JUnit format. (which isnt really a specified format; see https://blog.ilias.xyz/unit-test-output-formats-a-state-of-affairs-5734b4c8e577)
Converting the static analysis results into a test results format has been done a few times, such as early PEP8 plugins to Jenkins.  The mapping isnt exact, but the benefits of using the test result format is tight integration with various system.
CircleCI can accept this format: https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/collect-test-data/
AppVeyor can receive a test results XML format, in the format output by xunit, presumably the same as JUnit.
https://www.appveyor.com/docs/running-tests/#uploading-xml-test-results
The first project phase could involve converting the JSON to JUnit format and uploading into Circle CI and Appveyor.
The JUnit format should also be tested with a Jenkins install, to ensure it is uploading correctly there.  This would mean our Jenkins project is much less important.
Another common format is TAP.
And there is Clover XML format.
Then there are some system, such as Phabricator, which have a custom format they expect.
c.f. facebook/infer#673
The above probably doesnt fill 3 months.
Pulling the coala results from CI using this format could be a way to inform newbies of the style problems with their PRs.
Another way to expand this project is to also push the unit test results as XML to the CI (using combination XML files if necessary)

issue.title: Project proposal: Improve the projects website for use by other GSoC orgs
issue.body:
https://projects.coala.io/ should be easily usable by other GSoC orgs, and potentially other GCI orgs by the end of this GCI.
However, the needs of other orgs hasnt been taken into account when build it.
A reasonable project proposal was put together in 2017, at #226 , but has been closed as the project hadnt finished being defined.  As this type of project will tend to be 'easy' by default, a significant amount of analysis of other orgs requirements should be done before proposing the idea, in order to find challenges that make this project significant enough for GSoC.

issue.title: docs.coala.io: Header's aspect ratio not consistent (in mobile browsers)
issue.body:
Overview Description
The coala header in https://docs.coala.io/en/latest/ gets scaled only horizontally when viewed using mobile browsers leading to a distortion of the logo. It would be better if the consistency of the logo is maintained, else the koala bear starts looking like a starved chipmunk 😄
Steps to Reproduce

Open https://docs.coala.io/en/latest/ in any mobile web browser (portrait mode)

Actual Results

Expected Results
If the image scales while preserving aspect ratio and is aligned to the center or to the left, the logo would remain round.

No, you cannot delete a PR. Any PR. Only Close PR.
ok thanks

@akshatkarani if i delete this 8515861 commit. Would my PR gets deleted ?

It won't delete the PR, if you delete that commit.
You can delete that commit easily by using git interactive mode in terminal.
But, you need to squash your commits to one commit. Refer squashing section to know how to get into the interactive mode. Also, while you get into interactive mode, github provides some additional information on the terminal screen, please read those information carefully, as it will help you.
Also, use git commit --amend to add new local changes to your previous commit and then you can easily push this commit, without making an additional commits to the PR.

comments.bodyText:
Appveyor build is failing due to failing tests/general/URLHeadBearTest.py::URLHeadBearTestPrerequisites::test_check_prerequisites
And in this commit, line 18 assertion was changed from True to checking for a failed head request to the check_connection_url. Was this intentional or this change was just made for the test to pass?
According to me, as of the time of the above mentioned commit, the head request to the old IP was already failing which resulted in the failure of the test and hence the assertion was modified so that it passes albeit it being wrong.

Adding to the previous comment, I backtracked to the point the original test case was replaced by a faulty one, I got the following results,
While sending a GET resuest using requests on some URL say,http://random.url, the requests module explicitly appends a trailing /(forward-slash) if it is missing from the url, hence the final URL that actually gets called becomes http://random.url/. Owing to this fact, in the custom_matcher defined in InvalidLinkBearTest.py at L42,request.url == URLHeadBear.check_connection_url would always return False since the value of original check_connection_url was defined to be http://216.58.218.174(Note: no forward-slash). Hence this condition would never be possible and the value of the status_code of the default connection url would always be None, though this behaviour was never intended.
When the original test case for this was written, it was asserting True on the returned value of the output of URLHeadBear.check_prerequisites(). It would always return the error string You are not connected to the internet., and when asserting this return, the test would pass, incorrectly.
To overcome this, the test was modified in this commit, to assert for the returned string instead of the asserting True. This too was incorrect, since in the custom matcher the check_connection_url URL was explicitly defined(atleast intended) to return a status code of 200OK, but this line was never hit as mentioned in the first paragraph.
Hence URLHeadBear.check_prerequisites() while testing would always return the error string You are not connected to the internet. and hence as mentioned in the above commit, instead of changing the mock properties to actually return 200OK if the head request was to check_connection_url URL, the actual test case was modified to check against the error string which was never intended.
In my defense, I was sleepy when I made the commit

comments.bodyText: @soumya-ranjan7 @li-boxuan Review this please

@li-boxuan
I checked locally by adding JSONFormatBear on two sections and checked the appropriate message displayed when the json_sort value is either true or false.
Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this,
AssertionError: {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec04acf8>} != {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec05f9e8>}
This error is created by the check_results function inside LocalBearTestHelper.py .
It's comapring this whole string. But It should be comparing the Diff object's attribute values. This will always be false since the memory location will be always different.
In our codebase, the places where check_results is used was always used if the Diff object is None.
But here we are checking the message when the Diff is not None.
This type of test case is not tested previously. And check_results doesn't seem appropriate for this.
So what should I do in this case ?
Updated:
Approaches we can proceed with:
Creating a custom string reprsentation of diff object will resolve this.
Or defining a object.__eq__(self, other) function in coali.results.Diff would also work.

@naveentvelu check_results should work. Compare the strings from both of the Result objects yourself. (See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two). You  should be able to get your mistake, if not then post the entire pytest error on gitter.

@abhishalya
The check_results will not work because, we have a diff object which is not None. So when you compare two of them their ids get compared rather than their attributes.
If you see the above assertion error,
It is because of diffs(one of the attributes of 'result' class) which belongs to <class 'dict'>. This has a key-value pair filename : <class 'coalib.results.Diff.Diff'>.
In the current implementation of check_results, this key-value pair is directly being compared.This causes the assertion error.

See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two.

This is not needed here because there will always be mismatch in the id's of class objects even if they have the same attribute with same values.

@abhishalya @li-boxuan
Finally one of the approaches work, I added a def__repr__(self): function in Diff class. And It solved the above assertion error.
Should I create a issue along with PR for modifying the Diff class?
It's in coala/coala repo. https://github.com/coala/coala/blob/master/coalib/results/Diff.py

I was using check_results for the test cases.

Python34\lib\site-packages\coalib\testing\LocalBearTestHelper.py:228: in check_invalidity

E   AssertionError: 0 == 0 : The local bear 'PyLintBear' yields no result although it should.

The above error means that the problem is in the test case. Are you sure that you updating the Pylint version don't have to update the test cases? I mean can you verify that the functionality of the Pylint is still the same as it was in version 1.7.2
The Test for this bear is written here. It fails at line 31. The test file that this test use is here.
The appveryor fails because the test written at line 27
  self.section.append(Setting('pylint_disable', ''))
        self.check_invalidity(

            [],  # Doesn't matter, pylint will parse the file
            self.test_file)

when run, should produce some output/error message. FYI the above test case adds line something like disable=  in the configuration filie, which basically means to disable no errors. But it seems like(from the appveyor error) that, pylint isn't producing any error message.

issue.body:
This faq helps contributor in understanding about cEP and its
importance.
Closes #684

+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.

comments.bodyText: not well-designed content could be changed to poorly designed content for clarity
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to not well-designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.

comments.bodyText: creating projects -> created projects and expanding on -> expanded on in order to preserve parallel structure from contributed to
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to not well-designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.
+
+Anyone planning to do GSoC with coala should be starting to write detailed project ideas in our [projects](https://github.com/coala/projects) repository. Experience tells us that the best GSoC students are the ones who heavily contributed to the project ideas website, creating projects from the issues, and expanding on existing ***.md*** files. And generally learning how to express complex technical ideas in the markup. If you can't explain your idea, and how you will achieve it, we probably don't want to mentor you doing that undefined project.

issue.title: backends.py: Add profile_link function
issue.body:
This function is created to map github and gitlab usernames.
Ensures correct profile links are mapped for both websites.
Fixes #347
Reviewers Checklist

 Appropriate logging is done.
 Appropriate error responses.
 Handle every possible exception.
 Make sure there is a docstring in the command functions. Hint: Lookout for

+  <https://nodejs.org/>`__.
+
+::
+
+    $ node -v
+    v11.6.0
+
+    $ npm -v
+    6.5.0
+
+3. Install **bower** to build static web pages
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo npm install -g bower
+
+4. Change the directory to *coala-html* and run following command to install dependencies
+
+::
+
+    $ python setup.py install
+
+5. Install **coala-bears**
+
+::
+
+    $ pip install coala-bears
+
+6. Allow permissions to **root user** to install node packages
